meta.description: NestCheck reference address suite — ground truth for scoring regression tests
meta.usage: NES-89+ regression harness asserts actual scores fall within expected_range per dimension

parks.label: Parks & Green Space
parks.scoring: Continuous 0-10 (rounded daily_walk_value); nearest qualifying park >= 5 acres, >= 4.0 stars, >= 50 reviews

fitness.label: Fitness & Recreation
fitness.scoring: Discrete: 10 (>=4.2 stars + <=15 min), 6 (>=4.0 stars + <=20 min), 3 (<=30 min), 0 (else)

transit.label: Getting Around
transit.scoring: Composite: walk_to_stop (0-4) + frequency (0-3) + hub_travel (0-3), capped at 10

tiers.great: Clearly excels — top of scoring range

addresses.source: Consensus top-tier walkable neighborhood; Prospect Park anchor

parks.notes: Prospect Park (585 acres, 4.8 stars) is a 3-5 min walk

coffee.notes: Dozens of cafes on 5th and 7th Ave corridors; multiple within 10 min

grocery.notes: Key Food, Union Market, and others within 10-15 min walk

fitness.notes: Multiple well-rated gyms in the neighborhood

transit.notes: F/G at 7th Ave, R at 4th Ave-9th St, B/Q nearby; Manhattan hub <30 min

gas_station_proximity.notes: Residential area; nearest station well beyond 500ft

addresses.notes: Gold standard. If this doesn't score 85+, the model is miscalibrated.

addresses.source: Highly walkable Queens neighborhood; diverse food scene and strong transit

parks.notes: Astoria Park (60+ acres) exists but 15-20 min walk from Steinway; smaller parks closer

coffee.notes: Many cafes on Steinway St and Broadway corridors

grocery.notes: Trade Fair, Key Food, and specialty grocers on commercial streets

fitness.notes: Several gyms in the area

transit.notes: N/W at Steinway St station; M/R at 36th St. Frequent service to Manhattan

gas_station_proximity.notes: Commercial corridor but gas stations not immediately adjacent

addresses.notes: Tests that outer-borough neighborhoods score appropriately. Parks is the swing dimension — Astoria Park is large but not a quick walk from Steinway.

addresses.source: Classic Upper East Side; high-end residential with Central Park access

parks.notes: Central Park (843 acres, 4.8 stars) is 2-3 blocks west via cross streets

coffee.notes: Abundant cafes on Lexington, Madison, and nearby avenues

grocery.notes: Whole Foods, Trader Joe's, Eli's, and specialty grocers all walkable

fitness.notes: Multiple gyms including Equinox, YMCA, and boutique fitness

transit.notes: 6 train at 86th St, Q at 86th/2nd Ave; very frequent; Midtown hub <15 min

gas_station_proximity.notes: Residential UES; gas stations rare in this area

addresses.notes: Different flavor of exceptional — quieter and more residential than Park Slope but equally accessible. Tests that the model doesn't penalize low-key neighborhoods that have everything nearby.

addresses.source: Very walkable NJ city; grid street pattern, PATH train to Manhattan

parks.notes: Pier A Park, Elysian Park, Stevens Park — several small parks but none flagship-sized; may not meet 5-acre threshold

coffee.notes: Excellent cafe culture on Washington St and surrounding blocks

grocery.notes: ShopRite, Trader Joe's, Kings within walking distance

fitness.notes: Several gyms throughout compact city

transit.notes: PATH at Hoboken Terminal (~12-15 min walk from River St); NJ Transit buses closer. Walk to PATH is the limiting factor — walk_to_stop scores 3 at 12-15 min. Floor of 4 accounts for bus-only scenario; ceiling accounts for PATH frequency + hub proximity.

gas_station_proximity.notes: Waterfront area; no gas stations nearby

addresses.notes: Tests cross-state evaluation (NJ address using NYC transit). Parks qualification is the wildcard — Hoboken parks are charming but small. Transit score depends on PATH walk distance from northern Hoboken.

addresses.source: Small Hudson Valley village; walkable Main St but limited depth beyond it

parks.notes: Pierson Park on waterfront, Patriots Park nearby; no large flagship park

coffee.notes: Coffee Labs, Muddy Water Cafe on Main St; limited but walkable

grocery.notes: Some options near village center; larger stores may require driving

fitness.notes: Very limited gym options in the village proper

transit.notes: Metro-North Hudson Line at Tarrytown station; commuter frequency, not rapid transit

gas_station_proximity.notes: Gas stations on Route 9, likely >500ft from Main St

addresses.notes: Core Westchester use case. Tests the scorer's ability to distinguish 'some walkability' from 'truly walkable.' Midpoint of ranges is ~42% (Limited); could reach Moderate (60%) if coffee, grocery, and parks all hit range ceilings. Fitness and transit are the weak links. Charming village but a car is helpful beyond Main St.

addresses.source: Downtown Yonkers near Getty Square; some commercial activity but struggling area

parks.notes: Limited park options in immediate downtown area

coffee.notes: Some cafes and delis in Getty Square area; not a strong cafe scene

grocery.notes: Some grocery/bodega options in downtown Yonkers

fitness.notes: Very limited gym options in immediate area

transit.notes: Bee-Line bus routes; Metro-North (Yonkers station) nearby but walk may be 15+ min

gas_station_proximity.notes: Downtown commercial area; gas stations present but likely >500ft from this address

high_traffic_road.notes: Previously flagged by OSM road class; AADT below 50K threshold.

addresses.notes: Tests a struggling urban area that has some transit and walkable retail but lacks depth. South Broadway OSM classification is uncertain — if classified as secondary, could trigger high_traffic_road.

addresses.source: Suburban downtown; some walkability around commercial core

parks.notes: Battle Hill Park, Tibbits Park in downtown area; no large flagship

coffee.notes: Several cafes in downtown White Plains commercial district

grocery.notes: H Mart, some grocery options in downtown area

fitness.notes: Some gym options in commercial center

transit.notes: Metro-North at White Plains station; Bee-Line bus hub; commuter frequency

gas_station_proximity.notes: Downtown commercial; gas stations on periphery

addresses.notes: Prototypical suburban downtown. Has a walkable core but nothing exceptional. Tests the middle of the scoring range — everything is 'okay' but nothing stands out.

addresses.source: Highway-adjacent address next to Major Deegan Expressway (I-87); tests Tier 1 safety gate

parks.notes: Macombs Dam Park adjacent to Yankee Stadium

coffee.notes: Limited cafe options in immediate area

grocery.notes: Limited walkable grocery; bodegas but not full-service stores

fitness.notes: Limited gym options nearby

transit.notes: 161st St-Yankee Stadium station (B/D/4 trains); very frequent service

gas_station_proximity.notes: No gas station in immediate proximity

high_traffic_road.notes: Major Deegan Expressway (I-87) runs directly adjacent (~100-200 ft); AADT well above 50K threshold

addresses.notes: Primary Tier 1 highway test. Transit is excellent but most other dimensions are weak. Raw score lands ~30-40% (transit alone can't carry). Note: Tier 1 failure is a presentation flag — score is still calculated, so harness can assert BOTH tier1_pass=false AND score-in-band.

addresses.source: Commercial corridor with gas stations interspersed among residential; tests Tier 1 gas station gate

parks.notes: Crotona Park (127 acres) is within 10-15 min walk to the south

coffee.notes: Limited cafe scene on Tremont Ave; delis and bodegas dominate

grocery.notes: Some grocery options along Tremont commercial strip

fitness.notes: Limited gym options in immediate area

transit.notes: B/D at Tremont Ave station; Bx40/Bx42 buses on Tremont

gas_station_proximity.notes: Gas stations on Tremont Ave commercial strip likely within 500ft. Needs validation — exact station locations determine pass/fail.

high_traffic_road.notes: Previously flagged by OSM road class; AADT below 50K threshold.

addresses.notes: Tests gas station proximity gate. Tremont Ave has gas stations along its commercial stretch. This is the LEAST certain Tier 1 fail in the dataset — exact gas station distances need validation. If nearest station is >500ft, reclassify as a pass and move to a confirmed gas-station-adjacent address.

addresses.source: Consensus walkable urban neighborhood; Seattle's densest residential area

parks.notes: Cal Anderson Park (~7.5 acres, well-rated) ~5 min walk; Volunteer Park ~12 min. Cal Anderson is right at qualifying threshold.

coffee.notes: Coffee culture epicenter; Stumptown, indie roasters all over Broadway

grocery.notes: QFC on Broadway, Trader Joe's within walking distance

fitness.notes: Several gyms along Broadway corridor

transit.notes: Capitol Hill Link light rail ~5 min walk; frequent Metro buses on Broadway

gas_station_proximity.notes: Residential/commercial mix; no gas stations in immediate proximity

addresses.notes: Parks is the swing dimension. Cal Anderson at ~7.5 acres borders on the 5-acre qualification threshold. If it doesn't qualify, Volunteer Park at ~12 min drops parks to okay range. Neither park is Prospect Park caliber.

addresses.source: Quirky walkable neighborhood; strong local commercial core around Fremont center

parks.notes: Gas Works Park (20 acres, well-rated) ~10-12 min walk east; smaller green spaces closer

coffee.notes: Good cafe scene in Fremont center; multiple options within 5-10 min

grocery.notes: PCC Community Markets in Fremont; other options on nearby arterials

fitness.notes: Some gym options but not as dense as Capitol Hill

transit.notes: Frequent buses on Aurora Ave and Fremont Ave; no light rail (nearest future station at Ballard)

gas_station_proximity.notes: No gas stations in Fremont center

addresses.notes: Tests a neighborhood that's walkable but not transit-rich. Fremont has a strong local core but lacks rail. Fitness is the weakest dimension. Score depends heavily on whether Gas Works Park qualifies (20 acres, should meet threshold).

addresses.source: Residential Ballard; walkable commercial core nearby but this address tests the residential fringe

parks.notes: Golden Gardens (88 acres) exists but 20+ min walk west/downhill. Smaller parks closer. Qualification uncertain.

coffee.notes: Ballard Ave and Market St cafes are a 10-15 min walk south; nothing immediate

grocery.notes: Ballard Market, Fred Meyer ~10-15 min walk; Safeway further

fitness.notes: Some gyms in Ballard commercial core, 10-15 min walk

transit.notes: RapidRide D line on 15th Ave NW; local buses. No rail yet.

gas_station_proximity.notes: Residential street; no gas stations nearby

high_traffic_road.notes: Previously flagged by OSM road class; AADT below 50K threshold.

addresses.notes: Tests the residential fringe of a walkable neighborhood. Everything is 10-15 min walk rather than 5 min. Demonstrates how the same neighborhood can score differently depending on exact address placement.

addresses.source: University District near UW campus; high foot traffic, student-oriented commercial strip

parks.notes: Ravenna Park (58 acres, well-rated) within 10-15 min walk north; UW campus open space nearby

coffee.notes: Dense cafe strip on University Way ('The Ave'); many options within 5 min

grocery.notes: QFC, Safeway, and Asian grocery stores nearby

fitness.notes: Some public gyms; UW facilities not accessible to non-students

transit.notes: U-District Link light rail station; frequent Metro buses on University Way and 45th

gas_station_proximity.notes: No gas stations on this stretch of University Way

addresses.notes: Interesting test case: scores well on dimensions but vibe is student-oriented and noisy. Demonstrates that dimensional scoring and 'would you live here' can diverge. I-5 proximity is worth monitoring — if 200m threshold is marginal, this becomes an edge case.

addresses.source: Suburban city south of Seattle; some downtown walkability but car-oriented overall

parks.notes: Gene Coulon Memorial Beach Park on Lake Washington is walkable; pleasant but may not meet acreage/rating thresholds

coffee.notes: Some options in downtown Renton; limited quality cafe scene

grocery.notes: Some stores in downtown Renton area

fitness.notes: Limited walkable gym options

transit.notes: RapidRide F line connects to light rail; local buses. Frequency is moderate.

gas_station_proximity.notes: Downtown area; gas stations on periphery

addresses.notes: Tests the Seattle suburban tier. Has some walkable elements but car is practical for most errands. Rainier Ave proximity is an edge case for high_traffic_road check.

addresses.source: Diverse neighborhood south of downtown; light rail access but quieter commercial scene

parks.notes: Jefferson Park (48 acres, well-rated, great views) within 10 min walk

coffee.notes: Some cafes on Beacon Ave S; less dense than Capitol Hill or Fremont

grocery.notes: Red Apple Market, some small grocers on Beacon Ave

fitness.notes: Some gym options along Beacon Ave corridor

transit.notes: Beacon Hill Link light rail station; frequent buses on Beacon Ave

gas_station_proximity.notes: Residential area; no gas stations on McClellan

addresses.notes: Tests a neighborhood with good bones (light rail, large park) but weaker commercial amenities. Jefferson Park should score well if it qualifies — 48 acres and well-rated. Transit boost from Link station is significant.

addresses.source: Residential DC neighborhood with Metro access; some commercial activity on Georgia Ave

parks.notes: Grant Circle park, Raymond Recreation Center nearby; Rock Creek Park further west

coffee.notes: Some cafes on Georgia Ave and Upshur St corridors; growing but not dense

grocery.notes: Yes! Organic Market, some corner stores; larger chains require more walking

fitness.notes: Some gym options in the neighborhood

transit.notes: Petworth Metro (Green/Yellow); frequent buses on Georgia Ave

gas_station_proximity.notes: Gas stations exist on Georgia Ave but this block should clear 500ft

high_traffic_road.notes: Previously flagged by OSM road class; AADT below 50K threshold.

addresses.notes: DC moderate baseline. Georgia Ave OSM classification is a key uncertainty — if classified as primary, this becomes a Tier 1 fail candidate. At 4200 block, the address is set back from the worst of the traffic. Metro access lifts transit above other dimensions.

addresses.source: Premier walkable DC neighborhood; dense commercial core near Dupont Circle

parks.notes: Rock Creek Park (1,754 acres, 4.8 stars, thousands of reviews) should qualify and is 15-20 min walk west. At that walk time, daily_walk_value lands ~5-7. If Rock Creek does not qualify due to walk time >30 min, expected range drops to [3, 5].

coffee.notes: Excellent cafe scene on Connecticut Ave and side streets

grocery.notes: Trader Joe's on 14th St, Whole Foods, Safeway all within walking distance

fitness.notes: Multiple gyms in the Dupont/14th St corridor

transit.notes: Dupont Circle Metro (Red Line); frequent buses on Connecticut Ave

gas_station_proximity.notes: No gas stations near Dupont Circle core

addresses.notes: Could reach Exceptional if Rock Creek Park qualifies and scores well (pushing parks to 7+). Set band as Strong conservatively — parks is the single dimension keeping it from Exceptional. Everything else is top-tier.

addresses.source: Walkable inner suburb on Orange/Silver Metro line; dense mixed-use corridor

parks.notes: Courthouse area parks and playgrounds; no large flagship park within easy walk

coffee.notes: Many cafes on Wilson Blvd and Clarendon Blvd corridors

grocery.notes: Trader Joe's, Whole Foods, Harris Teeter all within walking distance

fitness.notes: Multiple gyms in the Clarendon commercial area

transit.notes: Clarendon Metro (Orange/Silver lines); frequent ART and Metrobus

gas_station_proximity.notes: No gas stations in Clarendon commercial core

high_traffic_road.notes: Previously flagged by OSM road class; AADT below 50K threshold.

addresses.notes: Tests walkable inner suburb pattern (as opposed to urban core). Very similar scoring profile to Capitol Hill Seattle but in DC metro. Parks is the weak dimension — Arlington has small pocket parks but nothing flagship-sized.

addresses.source: Revitalized DC corridor with strong retail, dining, and Metro access

parks.notes: Meridian Hill Park (12 acres, well-rated, historic) ~10 min walk. Should qualify on size and reviews.

coffee.notes: Dense cafe scene on 14th St NW corridor

grocery.notes: Giant at Columbia Heights Metro; Target with grocery; multiple options

fitness.notes: Several gyms along 14th St and U St corridors

transit.notes: Columbia Heights Metro (Green/Yellow lines); frequent buses on 14th St

gas_station_proximity.notes: No gas stations in this commercial stretch of 14th St

addresses.notes: Tests a revitalized urban corridor. Meridian Hill Park is the key parks test — 12 acres should qualify. If it does and walk time is ~10 min, parks scores solidly. 14th St OSM classification worth monitoring.

addresses.source: Car-dependent edge city with recent Metro addition; tests whether rail alone fixes walkability

parks.notes: No meaningful walkable parks; office park landscaping doesn't count

coffee.notes: Chain cafes in office/mall buildings; not walkable in traditional sense

grocery.notes: Whole Foods in Tysons exists but reaching it on foot means crossing wide arterials

fitness.notes: Gyms exist but car-oriented access

transit.notes: Tysons Corner Metro (Silver Line) is nearby but pedestrian access is through parking infrastructure

gas_station_proximity.notes: Office park area; gas stations on Route 7/123 but likely >500ft

high_traffic_road.notes: Previously flagged by OSM road class; AADT below 50K threshold.

addresses.notes: Key test: does adding a Metro station to a car-dependent area improve the score? Answer should be: somewhat (transit lifts), but not enough to overcome the absence of walkable amenities. Midpoint of dimension ranges is ~25% — firmly Significant Gaps. Route 7/123 proximity is a Tier 1 edge case.

addresses.source: Residential address directly on a major DC arterial (US Route 29); tests Tier 1 high-volume road gate

parks.notes: Fort Stevens Park, Takoma Rec Center nearby; small neighborhood parks

coffee.notes: Some options on Georgia Ave; not a strong cafe corridor at this block

grocery.notes: Some grocery stores along Georgia Ave commercial strip

fitness.notes: Limited gym options at this stretch of Georgia Ave

transit.notes: Frequent Metrobus routes on Georgia Ave; Takoma Metro is 15+ min walk north

gas_station_proximity.notes: Gas stations exist on Georgia Ave but not at every block

high_traffic_road.notes: Requires HPMS data verification. Georgia Ave (US-29) is a major arterial; previously flagged by OSM road class but urban AADT may be below 50K threshold.

addresses.notes: Primary test for high_traffic_road gate. Georgia Avenue is one of DC's busiest arterials — wide, high-speed traffic, classified as US Route 29. AADT needs HPMS verification to determine if it exceeds the 50K threshold. Midpoint of ranges is ~46% (Limited). Band is secondary to the Tier 1 assertion for this address.

addresses.source: Prototypical car-dependent DFW suburb; wide arterials, strip malls, no meaningful transit

parks.notes: Parks exist in Plano but not walkable from typical residential streets

coffee.notes: No walkable cafes; drive-to Starbucks in strip malls

grocery.notes: Drive-to grocery (Kroger, Tom Thumb) on major arterials

fitness.notes: Drive-to gyms in commercial strips. If this scores 3, validate that the matched gym is actually walkable and not across a 6-lane arterial with no sidewalk — known blindspot in walking time scoring.

transit.notes: DART bus is sparse at best; no rail. Effectively car-required.

gas_station_proximity.notes: Residential area; gas stations on arterials, not adjacent

high_traffic_road.notes: Previously flagged by OSM road class; AADT below 50K threshold.

addresses.notes: Canary address. If this scores above 39, the model is too generous to car-dependent suburbs. Everything here requires driving. Also tests: Independence Pkwy itself may trigger high_traffic_road — that's a useful edge case to validate.

addresses.source: Walkable beach city; strong commercial core with LA's best transit connection

parks.notes: Palisades Park along the bluffs, Tongva Park (6 acres). Beach/park access within 10 min walk.

coffee.notes: Many cafes on Montana Ave, Main St, and the Promenade area

grocery.notes: Multiple grocery options walkable in downtown Santa Monica

fitness.notes: Multiple gyms; beach fitness culture adds outdoor options

transit.notes: Expo/E Line at Downtown Santa Monica station; Big Blue Bus. Good by LA standards but frequency is lower than NYC/DC Metro.

gas_station_proximity.notes: Downtown commercial area; gas stations on periphery

addresses.notes: Tests LA walkability — rare in the metro but real in Santa Monica. Transit scores well by LA standards but won't match NYC/DC subway frequency. Interesting comparison to Seattle/DC Strong addresses.

addresses.source: Suburban LA city with some downtown walkability; car-oriented overall

parks.notes: Small city parks nearby; Brand Park is up in the hills, not walkable. No qualifying flagship.

coffee.notes: Some cafes in downtown Glendale; Armenian cafe culture adds options

grocery.notes: Ralphs, ethnic grocery stores in downtown area

fitness.notes: Some gyms in commercial area

transit.notes: Some Metro bus routes; no rail in Glendale. Beeline local buses.

gas_station_proximity.notes: Gas stations exist on Central Ave but likely >500ft from this block

addresses.notes: Tests LA suburban city pattern. Has more walkability than pure sprawl (Plano) but still car-dependent for most trips. Central Ave OSM classification is uncertain — could be a Tier 1 edge case.

addresses.source: Mueller New Urbanist development; designed for walkability in a car-centric city

parks.notes: Mueller Lake Park, Southwest Greenway designed into the development; multiple green spaces within walking distance

coffee.notes: Some cafes in Mueller commercial areas and along Aldrich St; not as dense as established urban cores

grocery.notes: H-E-B on Mueller Blvd within walking distance; designed into the development

fitness.notes: Some gym options in Mueller commercial area

transit.notes: Cap Metro bus routes serve Mueller; Austin transit is generally weak. No rail nearby.

gas_station_proximity.notes: Planned development; no gas stations in residential area

high_traffic_road.notes: Previously flagged by OSM road class; AADT below 50K threshold.

addresses.notes: Tests whether New Urbanist design translates to good scores. Parks should score well (designed-in green space). Transit is the drag — even good urban design can't fix a weak transit system. Interesting contrast to older walkable neighborhoods.

addresses.source: Sprawling Phoenix suburb; extreme car dependence and heat-hostile pedestrian environment

parks.notes: Riverview Park area exists but walkability is questionable in Phoenix heat and road design

coffee.notes: No walkable cafes; chain drive-throughs on arterials

grocery.notes: Drive-to grocery on major roads

fitness.notes: Drive-to gyms

transit.notes: Valley Metro bus with very low frequency; no rail in this part of Mesa

gas_station_proximity.notes: Gas stations on McKellips but residential setback should clear 500ft

addresses.notes: Second canary address alongside Plano. Different Sun Belt pattern (Phoenix vs DFW) — both should score rock-bottom. McKellips Road classification is uncertain; if primary in OSM, this becomes a Tier 1 fail too.

addresses.source: Walkable arts district with strong independent business scene

parks.notes: Alberta Park (16 acres) directly on Alberta St within 5-10 min walk; should qualify on size

coffee.notes: Excellent indie coffee scene on Alberta St; Portland coffee culture is strong

grocery.notes: New Seasons, smaller markets within walking distance; not as dense as downtown cores

fitness.notes: Some gym options in the neighborhood; not as dense as major commercial corridors

transit.notes: TriMet bus routes on Alberta and MLK; MAX Yellow Line is 10-15 min walk south. Good bus frequency.

gas_station_proximity.notes: No gas stations in Alberta Arts commercial core

high_traffic_road.notes: Previously flagged by OSM road class; AADT below 50K threshold.

addresses.notes: Tests Portland walkability pattern — strong indie commercial strips with good parks but more moderate transit than NYC/DC. Alberta Park is the key parks test (16 acres, should qualify). Transit is the limiting dimension.

addresses.source: Major arterial corridor (US Route 40); tests combined high-volume road and potential gas station proximity failure

parks.notes: City Park (330 acres, major Denver park) is ~15-20 min walk south; if it qualifies, parks could score well despite the address being on Colfax

coffee.notes: Limited quality cafes on this stretch of East Colfax; some diners and fast food

grocery.notes: Some small markets on Colfax; major grocery stores require more walking

fitness.notes: Limited gym options on this stretch of Colfax

transit.notes: RTD Route 15/15L on Colfax (one of Denver's most frequent bus routes); no rail at this location

gas_station_proximity.notes: Gas stations are common along Colfax Ave commercial strip. High likelihood of one within 500ft. Needs validation.

high_traffic_road.notes: Requires HPMS data verification. Colfax Ave (US-40) is a major multi-lane arterial; previously flagged by OSM road class but AADT may be below 50K threshold.

addresses.notes: Tests combined Tier 1 failures. Colfax is the longest commercial street in America and a major arterial — may trigger high_traffic_road pending HPMS data verification. Gas station proximity is likely but needs validation. Interesting that transit scores okay (frequent bus) despite the address being inhospitable for pedestrians.

addresses.source: Dense urban core in Miami; walkable high-rise neighborhood with Metrorail

parks.notes: Brickell Key Park, Alice Wainwright Park — small urban parks. No large flagship within easy walk.

coffee.notes: Many cafes and restaurants throughout Brickell's dense commercial ground floors

grocery.notes: Publix, Whole Foods within Brickell; dense enough for walkable grocery access

fitness.notes: Multiple high-end gyms in Brickell towers and commercial spaces

transit.notes: Brickell Metrorail station; free Metromover. Decent frequency but Miami transit overall is limited compared to northeastern cities.

gas_station_proximity.notes: Dense urban area; gas stations pushed to periphery

high_traffic_road.notes: Previously flagged by OSM road class; AADT below 50K threshold.

addresses.notes: Tests Sun Belt urban walkability — Brickell is Miami's attempt at a walkable urban core. Parks is the weak dimension (no flagship). Interesting comparison to car-dependent Sun Belt addresses — same region, vastly different walkability.

addresses.source: Houston Galleria area; major commercial destination that is still car-dependent despite density

parks.notes: Gerald Hines Waterwall Park is small/decorative. No substantial walkable park.

coffee.notes: Chain cafes inside Galleria complex; not traditional walkable street-front cafes

grocery.notes: Grocery stores exist nearby but crossing Post Oak Blvd on foot is hostile

fitness.notes: Gyms in the commercial area; one of the stronger dimensions here

transit.notes: METRO bus routes; Post Oak BRT under development. Currently car-dominant.

gas_station_proximity.notes: Gas stations on arterials but Galleria-area setbacks should clear 500ft

high_traffic_road.notes: Previously flagged by OSM road class; AADT below 50K threshold.

addresses.notes: Tests the 'looks dense but isn't walkable' pattern. Houston Galleria has commercial density but hostile pedestrian infrastructure (wide roads, no sidewalk culture). Midpoint of dimension ranges is ~28% — Significant Gaps despite the commercial density. Post Oak Blvd classification is the Tier 1 edge case. Gym scores slightly better than other dimensions because commercial fitness facilities exist in the area.
